intro: Anisopappus oliverianus, commonly known as the desert sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, tubular flowers that range in color from pink to purple. The plant produces small, papery bracts that are often mistaken for leaves, and its foliage is typically covered in fine, white hairs that help reduce water loss. Anisopappus oliverianus is adapted to harsh desert conditions, with deep roots and a low-growing habit that allows it to survive in sandy, well-drained soils.
